well it appears as though Lance Armstrong is on the way to his sixth consecutive Tour de France....
 
 can anything stop him? 
 
 the cancer couldn't, the drug allegations probably won't, other cyclists...forget that....
 
 what are your thoughts? Of course...you know he's TEXAN :p

Of course he'll win, he's all steroided up. :p 
 
 Seriously though, that man is INCREDIBLE.
 
 He'll win again, and continue to win as long as he wants too.
 
 Waxy

I voted for the "Texan" ;) to win again.
 
 He's not only got the physical capabilities, but he's been at it long enough that his knowledge of the game will carry him further than most.

I was listening to them talk about his training the other day and they said that before the tour actually starts he has riden the course like 2 1/2 times in training in the 2 months prior to that...not to mention a very strict training routine....I like to see guys like him come back from possible life ending/career ending things like he did...pretty awesome story.
Well, we're batting 1000 - looks like he did it again.

Well, we're batting 1000 - looks like he did it again.

 
 Being a long-time cycling fan, I loved the fact that OTL had nightly in-depth broadcasts of the day's stage. For Lance to go from not willing an individual stage in 2003 to winning 5? in 2004 and 64? in total is another incredible feat.
 I believe that Fitness magazine may be touting him as the greatest athlete ever. Some interesting facts: Lance Armstrong's resting heart rate is 32; he has a 130% lung capacity when compared to an average person.
 This AM, I listened to two radio DJ's discussing the claim that Lance is the greatest athlete. They argued that Michael Jordon was a more deserving choice. They said that if you gave MJ 2 years to learn cycling, he'd beat LA in a race, but if you taught LA basketball, he'd get killed.
 I had to turn the radio at that point. MJ would get smoked on the bike so badly that it would be a joke. For one thing, the sports take differing muscle types. B-ball players need fast-firing muscles in order to jump and sprint. Cyclists need slow-firing muscles for their endurance. The two, while not totally mutually exclusive, aren't found to nearly the same degree in any given individual.
 Way to go, Lance. You showed the frogs who's #1 once again. emoticon_xgood
